result.execSummary:
The defendant Teresa Lynn Charest was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case. One or more other charges in this case were dismissed. The dismissed charges were not proven and have no legal effect. Teresa Lynn Charest is presumed innocent of the dismissed charges.

  • Teresa Lynn Charest was found guilty of Disorderly Conduct, a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: *Submit DNA sample and pay surcharge.  *Payment Plan of $50.00 per month, commencing 9/1/16.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

Marquette County DNA Proof of Submission

Defendant Teresa Lynn Charest in court with attorney Mark Jay Gumz.  Chad A. Hendee appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
15CM153 & 15CM183 tracking together:
  Atty Hendee states plea agreement to Ct. 2 in 15CM153 and Ct. 1 in 15CM183.  Count 1 in 15CM153 and Ct. 2 in 15CM183 to be dismissed.  Atty Gumz agrees.
Defendant agrees and enters a No Contest plea.
  Court questions defendant regarding plea. Advises of Constitutional Rights and elements of the charge.  Court finds plea made knowingly, voluntarily & Intelligently.    Court relies on the criminal complaint in both cases for a factual basis.

  BY THE COURT:  Court finds a sufficient factual basis to support the charges.  Court accepts defendant's plea and finds defendant guilty of Ct. 2 in 15CM153 and Ct. 1 in 15CM183.  Count 1 in 15CM153 and Ct. 2 in 15CM183 to be dismissed.

Atty Hendee asks the court to follow the joint recommendation.
Atty Gumz makes sentencing arguments and asks the court to follow the joint recommendation.

BY THE COURT:  15CM153:  Ct. 2:  Court orders 5 days in the Marquette County Jail
